title: Clinical Study of TripleA Connected to Diagnosis, Care and Aftercare of Alcohol Addiction in Outpatient Care
description_brief: The primary objective is to investigate differences in the alcohol consumption pattern between alcohol addicts receiving conventional treatment and those who receive a combination of conventional treatment and TripleA.
description_detailed:
The study is a 12-month open-label and randomised comparison between the control group receiving only conventional treatment and the intervention group receiving conventional treatment enhanced with TripleA.

The studies have been designed to reflect as far as possible the conventional care for alcohol dependence. The TripleA product is intended to strengthen the existing methods used during the assessment phase, treatment phase and aftercare of alcohol dependence.

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Patients were recruited at two sites (Uppsala University Hospital and Nämndemansgården) beginning in October 2015 . Recruitment continued until January 2017 and the last follow-up visits were conducted in December 2017 (Uppsala University Hospital) and in January 2018 (Nämndemansgården), respectively.

groups.title: Conventional Treatment and TripleA
groups.description: Conventional treatment and TripleA medical device consisting of alcoholometer, a Bluetooth mobile app on cell phone and information stored on computer for caregiver

groups.title: Conventional Treatment
groups.description: Conventional treatment may be medication or 12-step addiction treatment according to the Minnesota model.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Patients (n=115) were recruited to clinical trials from a 12-step aftercare programme(12S-ABS) and from hospital care with abstinence (HC-ABS) or controlled drinking (HC-CDR) as goal. The subject population for study KC102-001 was formed by 71 subjects enrolled at Uppsala University Hospital. Study KC102-002 included 44 subjects registered at Nämndemansgårdens treatment home.

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Patients With no Heavy Drinking Days After 12 Months
outcomeMeasures.description: Difference between the treatment arms in percentage of patients with no heavy drinking days during the 4-weeks period before the 12 months follow-up visit .
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Of the planned patient number (216 patients) only approximately 25% or less was analyzed due to poor recruitment rate and a high drop-out of patients during the study.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Four weeks period before the 12 months visit

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Total Amount of Consumed Alcohol From the Baseline Visit to the 6 Months Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of drinks during the 4 weeks period before the baseline visit minus number of drinks during the 4 weeks period before the 6 months visit. A positive difference means a reduction in drinking. A negative difference means increased drinking.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: The four weeks-period before the baseline visit and before the 6 months visit

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Health Outcome, Measured With the Visual Analog Scale (EQ VAS) in EQ-5D at the Baseline Visit Compared to the 6 Months Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in health outcome, measured with the visual analog scale (EQ VAS) in EQ-5D after 6 months compared to baseline. The EQ-5D is a standardized instrument for measuring and describing health outcomes. VAS score is 0-100 where 0 is the worst possible health and 100 is the best possible health. A positive difference indicates improvement.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Degree of Alcohol Dependence Measured as the Difference in SADD-points at Baseline Compared to 6 Months
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in degree of alcohol dependence measured as the difference in Short Alcohol Dependence Data (SADD)-points at baseline minus 6 months Scoring: The 15 items summed for a total score than can range from 0 to 45. Scale totals are interpreted as follows: 1-9 low dependence, 10-19 medium dependence, and 20 or greater high dependence. A large positive number indicates a better result.

outcomeMeasures.description: Change in degree of alcohol dependence measured as the difference in Short Alcohol Dependence Data (SADD)-points at baseline minus 12 months. Scoring: The 15 items summed for a total score than can range from 0 to 45. Scale totals are interpreted as follows: 1-9 low dependence, 10-19 medium dependence, and 20 or greater high dependence. A large positive number indicates a better result.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Concentration of the Alcohol Metabolite CDT in the Blood at Baseline Compared to 6 Months
outcomeMeasures.description: CDT (Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin) concentration is given in % of total transferrin in serum, i e. CDT(%). The change is calculated as baseline CDT (%) minus CDT(%) at 6 months. A large positive difference indicates decreased drinking.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Safety with collection of adverse events was followed for each patient from Baseline (start of study) until the 12-month visit (end of study).

eventGroups.title: Conventional Treatment and TripleA
eventGroups.description: Conventional treatment and TripleA medical device consisting of alcoholometer, a Bluetooth mobile app on cell phone and information stored on computer for caregiver

eventGroups.title: Conventional Treatment
eventGroups.description: Conventional treatment consisting of medication treatment or the Minnesota model of addiction treatment

seriousEvents.notes: Ascites due to liver cirrhosis. Not related to device.
Bleeding esophagusvarices and duodenal ulcus. Not related to device.
Staphylococcus aureus sepsis. Not related to device.
Hospitalization due to alcohol abstinence. Not related to device.
Infection in foot after surgery. Not related to device.

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

seriousEvents.notes: Intoxication, lowered consciousness and delirium. Not related to device.

otherEvents.notes: Five patients reported cold, or flu-like symptoms and fever.
Four patients reported pain in foot, hand, or thumb.

limitationsAndCaveats.description:
Due to unrealistic assumptions in the sample size calculations, difficulties in recruiting subjects and high dropout rate, the study was inconclusive.

The poor recruitment rate and poor retention of patients in the study was a challenge (in addition with the quality of self-reported outcomes). The drop-out rate, especially between month 6-12, was a problem both in treatment and control groups.

drug: TripleA (medical device — alcoholometer + Bluetooth mobile app + caregiver data system)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests TripleA added to conventional treatment to reduce alcohol use (primary outcome: alcohol consumption pattern/no heavy drinking days). The intervention is described as a Device, not a drug, and is intended to support diagnosis, care and aftercare of alcohol dependence. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted trial details — Intervention: Device: TripleA (medical device consisting of an alcoholometer, a Bluetooth mobile app on a cell phone, and information stored on a computer for the caregiver); Lead sponsor: Kontigo Care AB; Registry/ID: NCT03195894. This confirms TripleA is a digital/monitoring device rather than a biologic or small-molecule drug. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Reflect: Classification — The four Alzheimer’s-related categories are specific to pharmacologic or biologic interventions targeting Alzheimer pathology, cognitive enhancers, or treatments for neuropsychiatric symptoms. This study evaluates a digital/medical device for alcohol use disorder, so it does not fit any of the Alzheimer’s target categories; therefore the correct classification is 'N/A'. No placebo is listed in the trial description. citeturn0search1turn0search2
